Yes, I should had bought a copy of that index when it was offered "many years ago." Editor of the Newsletter at the time, I recall the author(s) placing a one-time ad in the Newsletter offering their index for, I think, around fifty bucks. Never got around to buying a copy at the time; too tight to pay today's price for it now. Thanks for looking up the owl, Craig. Will check it out.

Ron
STL
  ----- Original Message ----- 
  From: Craig Harris 
  To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com 
  Sent: Saturday, July 19, 2003 2:16 PM
  Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] What does owl symbolize?


  Once again, Tompkins' "People, Places and Things In Henri Joly's 
  Legend in Japanese Art" comes to the rescue with a reference on p. 
  122 and p. 544 in addition to the one you found on p. 43, Ron.

  Unfortunately my copy of Legend is not here at the moment, so someone 
  else will have to look those up and report.

  Craig Harris


  On Sat, 19 Jul 2003 13:54:29 -0500, Ron Hartmann wrote:
  >Hi -
  >
  >I found a brief explanation in Joly's "Legend in Japanese Art" on
  >p.43 but could find nothing elsewhere in the book about owls. (You
  >need the Japanese name for "owl" to find it, if it exists.)
  >
  >In the 2-volume set "Tsuba" and "Kodogu" by (I think) H.U.B. Velag--
  >German publication from a few years ago--the Kodogu volume shows a
  >kozuka (KO-51) with an owl being used as falcon bait, and a kogai 
  (K-
  >11)showing an owl on a tree branch. Each item has a description of
  >the design explaining the evilness of the owl (poor guy).
  >
  >This is all I could find here.
  >
  >Ron
  >STL
